text: Bottle while cooking Hamburgers. Golden pour with creamy off white head that dissipated to a ring. Aroma is pine, caramel and citrus. Mouthfeel is nice with a medium body and crisp carbonation. Taste is dry sweetness followed by a nice hop bitterness that extends through the finish.

July 19th, 2014 - I come to the end of another Beer Camp box, wrapping up with the There and Back ESB, a frilly, foamy and clear beer with a lot of sizzle and perk. The aroma is light and sweet, with sticky caramel and toffee and a touch of a botanical note, relatively sweet for an ESB. The taste is on the sweeter side, though more mineral tasting up front, with clove and all-spice kicking in later on. Theres also a mineral water finish, with a pinch of those sugared almonds, and ending with a curious whip of smoke. Really excellent and engaging for an ESB, this is a worthy finish to the box.

12 oz bottle from Beer Camp series. Pours a mostly clear, deep Amber color and topped by a small layer of off white foam that settles into a thin film. The aroma shows notes of floral hops, hints of citrus fruit, biscuits, toffee and caramel malts. There is also some pine hop resin on the back end. The flavor follows and is malty up front with notes of toasted bread, biscuits, caramel and toffee and balanced out nicely with some floral and piney hop bitterness. Medium bodied and smooth with balanced carbonation that leads to a slightly sweet and bitter finish. Not really my favorite style, but still solid and well done.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a hazy orange-caramel color with a few tiny floaters and a large fluffy orange-white head that lingered and left decent lacing. The aroma was bitter and biscuity with a bit of caramel and fruity hops. The flavor was bitter and somewhat tart with notes of toffee, biscuit, a hint of wood and tobacco. Long finish. Medium body. Ok.

(Bottle, 0.355 l, at laitis, 20150613) The beer poured amber and almost clear. Its head was small and white. Aroma had lots of toffee and strongly malts. Palate was medium bodied with rather high carbonation. Flavours were malts, frutiness, sweetness and bitterness. Aftertaste was sweet and bitter. This was no Bitter, instead it was more like a sweet Amber ale.
Amber pour with a small head. Sweet grainy aroma with a decent hop punch. Flavor is smooth and clean. A nice bitter component. One of the better bitters Ive had.

12 oz bottle, served in a schooner. Pours dark orange, slightly hazy golden with medium cream colored head. Aroma is rich, sweet chewy caramel and toffee malt. Taste is similar - rich coating mouthfeel and big caramel malt flavor. Slightly dry and oaky mid-palate. Hoppier than I was expecting on the finish, given the IBU here. Balances the big malts well, finshes clean. Excellent beer. Wish more U.S. breweries would do bitters.

355ml bottle - thanks VastActiv! (6:3+:6-:3:11=2.9)
WTF style? Nutty aroma, but no esters at all. Simple malty taste, and a bit woody. This isnt a bitter, its a shambolic mess. At least it was made with beer ingredients, you can at least tell that.

Bottle. The pour is almost a light but vibrant reddish color, hazy. The aroma has some nice bitterness to it, some floral notes. The taste is solid, spot on for the style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330ml bottle @laitis, thanks. Hazy amber color. Tiny to almost no head. Sweet, caramel, fruity and hops in aroma. Caramel, hops, citrus in taste. Soft bitterness. Hops in aftertaste. Feels thin and watery.
Bottle 12 fl oz at Laitis, Helsinki. Colour is deep orange with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, nuts, bitterness, some hops and malts.

Tap at Sidedoor. Filtered orange body. Thinnish off-white head. Pretty true to style. Sweet English malts, toffee, amber malt. A little leaning into the malt, not much hop balance...surprising for Sierra...more of a NG beer. SOme quality malts, but overall kind of boring, standard.

Bottle at home. Not really a fan of the style but this I like. That pretty much says it all. Has enough hop notes to hold my interest but the biscuit, bready, maltiness of the style is still there upfront. Applealing hazy/burnt orange color. Definite fruit notes notes- tropical, citrus and plum in the finish. Definitely more hoppy than your typical bitter, but about what I would expect from a SN collab.

Bottle. Amber copper, light hazy. Malty dry caramels, some biscuits, earthy light herby hops. Med bodied, bit thin finnish. Med bitter, some huskyness, malty caramels, foresty pine. Clean med tasty, easily drunk, bitter.-- bb

355ml bottle, thanks jookos!
Deep amber,  thick white head.  Nice biscuity,  malty aroma,  some caramel.  Flavor has  crackers,  malt,  English hops,  fudgy sweetness,  some plummy notes. Long finish.  Not bad.
Bottle. Dark amber. Some lacing and decent lasting bit of head. Mildly coffee malt nose. Nice hop bite, almost rye quality at front flows into slightly bitter fruitiness.

Bottle at home in Salisbury. Pours mostly clear orange-gold with a foamy off-white head. Lots of tropical fruits in the nose - interestingly - with notes of melon, some berries, papaya and mandarin orange. Light-medium sweet flavor with more juicy fruit character, citrus, pale bread, slight piney bitterness. Light to medium bodied with average carbonation. Moderately sweet on the finish with more juicy citrus and other fruits, pale bread, tropical stuff, orange, tangerine, faint bubblegum, some pale crackers. Very tasty but nothing like an English bitter.

[Tap] Amber in color with a little bit of haze to it. About a half inch of white head on top. Aromas of biscuit malts, fruity hops and mild grass. Flavors of caramel malts, toasted bread, grain husks, some fruits and earthy hops. Very drinkable. Average body. Decent balance, but more of a pale ale than a traditional Bitter. Tasting notes from 7/2014.
Bottle. Hazy amber color with fleeting ivory head. Fruity, toasted caramel, nutty aromas. Medium bodied. Toasted caramel, mild pit fruit, earthy flavors----decent.

text: Light amber pour with an off-white head. Aroma is earthy tones, malty. Taste is a malty base with earthy hops. Tasty and easy to drink. OK lacing.
Not a style I usually do. Caramel grains toast and toffee. Marzen like.Hops sour note. Mineral water metallic finish ruins this. Finished is bitter dry hops
Pours muddy amber with a beige head. Aroma of caramel, cereal, biscuit, and light hops. Easy to drink but I like my bitters with a little more hop bite.

Pours orange-amber with a persistent off-white foam. Aroma is fruity (berries, hint of plum), toffee, biscuit, and slight diacetyl. Taste is berry, mild citrus, malty, a bit herbal, caramel/toffee, and cereal. Light-med body, low bitterness. Pretty nice and easy drinking.

tap - This brew has a rich caramel aroma with notes of citrus. It tastes of sweet caramel malt and moderately bitter hops with a subtle citrus character. Its medium bodied, soft on the palate, and easy drinking. Very good.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2015 January 9, 2015. Bottle at home, bottled may 22, 2014.
Clear dark amber with a medium sized white head. Aroma is malty, biscuit, toffee, dark berries. Taste is light to medium sweet, malty, dark berries, light bitter.Finish is light bitter with herbal, fruity and biscuit notes. Medium bodied, average carbonation.
Amber with a tight white head. Aroma is a nice piney hoppiness, mild malt, nice aroma. Taste is a nice solid hoppiness with pine and floral notes, balanced by a subtle malt presence.

35,5 cl bottle @ tiong, packaged 22.05.2014
Aroma has gooseberry bush and caramel malt. Also cereal. Flavour has fruity hops, cereal, gooseberry bush and some grapefruit. Also some sweet caramel malt. Could be better fresh. This is over seven months old but still the hops are way more strong than in bitters usually.

355ml bottle from Saveur-Biere
PKGD 05/22/14 - Pours reddish orange with a small white head. Aroma of fruits, caramel, hints of toffee, bready malts and herbal notes. Taste is bland, slightly malty and bready with some toffee, caramel, herbal hops and grass. Finish is sweetish, slightly bitter and malty with some toffee, caramel and herbal notes. Quite easy going and malty bitter.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a nice murky orange amber with off white head. Aroma is earthy and grass notes, toffee, caramel. Moderately sweetness and bitterness. Flavors of caramel, bread, biscuits, toffee, and pine and citrus. Very smooth. Excellent English bitter that makes an awesome session beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of the best American made bitters Ive had. Malty and light at the end. Biscuity with some light caramel sweetness at the end. One of three I managed to try at Blind Tiger in 2014.

Shiny gold-copper color with a large, pillowy off-white head. Toffee malt in the aroma with a nice dose of earthy - herbal hops. The flavor is soft and chewy English biscuits with a touch of caramel paired with a well-balanced level of h e bal and earthy hops. The bitterness level is just right for the style. The is a slight nutiness as the beer warms. Medium body, super smooth and soft on the tongue making it almost cask-like. Overall, this is a fantastic Bitter and is extremely well put together and sessionable. I like it quite a bit and wish it were available regularly in 6-packs!

This was shared with Strykzone on Facebook Chat. Poured golden amber with a small white head. Light lacing. Nose of light malts and some floral hops. Medium in body. Flavor is malts and floral hops. Finish is a little astringent and some light fruit appears. Different than your average bitter. But very nice drinking.

On tap @ The Torpedo Room. Apparently I never rated this despite having had it from the mixed pack. Clear copper pour with a white head. Really nice floral hops on the nose. Somewhat spicy and some grassy hops as well. Nice toasted malt and bread. Solid malt base on the palate. Good bready flavor and sweetness. Plenty of spicy and floral hops. Some mild bitterness of grass and herbs.

On draft. Orange in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of pale malt, orchard fruit, and sweet orange. In the mouth there is more generic pale malt, orange gumdrops, and an undertone of earthy hops. Medium bodied with a mild but persistent bitterness. Decent enough overall, but I was expecting more considering the brewers. Lacking in a bit of authenticity for the style too.

Bottle, pours clear orange copper, minimal khaki head. Nose is muted, earthy malts, graham cracker, subtle dark fruits. Much of the same on the palate as there's a pleasant bitterness on the finish but the flavor profile lacks complexity 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Found this floating in the back of the fridge. Poured an amber orange color. Heavy on the malt, a little bit nutty, a little bit straw-y. Seems like a pretty well-made beer, yet kinda boring. I suppose that goes with the style a little though.

Bottle poured into a shaker. Pours a hazy rust orange with a half finger off white head. Aroma of herbal and grassy hops with a hint of toffee. Taste is light bitter. Citrus and herbal hops. Light bodied with a thin texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish.
Beautiful dark amber pour. Simple malty aroma, not much complexity but very pleasant palate, medium body and creamy. Good overall, not great.

Pours out a nice darker golden color with a small white head. Aroma is of lots of caramel, subtle herbal notes, grassy bitterness, dough and some grains. Taste is clean, dough, caramel, grains, wet bread, light grassy/herbal hops. These just arent my style.
Piney, bready, and slightly biscuity. Not bad, but lacks depth and character.

Small, off white head with fair retention and lace.Hazy amber color. Slight nose, fruity, slight banana esters.Light bodied, decent carbonation. Dry malts, slight grain, some cardboard. Dry finish, lightly fruity, no bitterness. Bland. Draft/growlered from statelineliquors.
Orange pour foamy head. Citrus and caramel aroma. Nice malty body caramel but little sweetness coming through and nice citrus bite. Little herbal. Moderate body light carbonation enjoyable.
Pours an orange copper color with aroma of nuts, toffee, and hops. Toffee and citrus flavor with subtle hop bite. Very nice.
Bottle thanks to sonnycheeba. Pours an orangish amber with off white head. Aroma and taste of malts and some caramel.
Bottle. Deep caramel with a large, beige head. Light fruit with a Pilsner bite. Tart and dry. Fantastic.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber orange with a large creamy white head. Soft toffee and hops on the nose, a bit of citrus and nutty malt. Medium bodied, malty and smooth, cool vibrant hops and a touch of caramel. Finishes slowly with lingering hop bitterness and a crackery malt note.

First rating for the Bitter style. 12 ounce bottle as part of the Beer Camp Across America 12-pack. Pours a clear pumpkin-colored orange hue with two fingers of white foam with decent retention. AROMA of musty grains, toasted nuts, honey malts, and light caramel. FLAVOR of smooth caramel, light citric hops, toasted bready malts, and honey. Finishes lightly sweet with only a hint of hop bitterness. Light body and mouthfeel. Not sure how true to style this might be as I am unfamiliar with the style...seems like a slightly hoppy amber ale to me. Nicely quaffable, but I might have preferred New Glarus doing something along the lines of their excellent fruit beers in this collaboration. (380, 923)

Slightly hazy golden coloured body with a bit of a honey and orange glow and a nice, relatively fast-dying one centimetre tall just off-white head. Aroma of yeast, pale malt, a touch of grassy and herbal hops and a very subdued apricot smell. Light-bodied; Strong malt flavour at first with hints of tropical and citrus fruits, then follows up with a touch of bitterness and a little earth and funk on the end. Aftertaste is relatively straight forward with some grassy hop notes, touches of herbs and citrus and very little else. Overall, not a bad beer, but nothing too exciting. If you didnt know New Glarus had a part in this (or the label didnt say otherwise), this beer wouldnt be rated so highly. I love NG beers just as the next person, but this is all a reputation rating here, there is nothing to see here. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Harris Teeter in Arlington (Pentagon City), Virginia on 30-July-2014 for US$22,00 for the twelve pack, sampled at home in Washington, a few blocks away on 30-October-2014.
bottle. Red amber with one finger head. Toffee and caramel malt body. Toast and nuts. Mild bitterness from the hops. Quite well constructed.

Pours a finger of head on a clear straw colored body.
The aroma is mild lemon, dried apricot, and wet grains.
The taste is fruity sweet upfront, lemon bitter follows. Nice balance, tends sweet overall.
The texture is sticky.
Enjoyable.

Amber color with a thin white head. Aroma is light grassy hops with a touch of toffee. Flavor is surprisingly hoppy for a bitter, makes it a bit crisp. Malt comes in the finish, a bit of toffee with some very light nuttiness. Pleasant.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2015 Comes out of ye olde tap slightly hazy golden with a thick light tan head. Aroma is malty with a fruity undertone. Flavor has strong malty and fruity - apple and pear - notes plus a bit of woody hops. Mouthfeel is quite lively and sassy. Get into the Hobbit of enjoying this.

12-bottle. Pours a bright copper color with a frothy tan head with lots of big bubbles. Full mouthfeel. Medium body. Great hop-over-malt flavor balance. Mellow hop flavor with underlying maltiness. Very nice.
(Bottle) This is a excellent. Nice aroma, beautiful appearance (although I wish it had better head retention), and great flavor. Its got a bit of an overly-bitter aftertaste. Impressive beer.
On draft. Red orange color with off white head. Fruity aroma. Slight fruit taste and malt. Bitter finished. Delicious.

For a bitter, its really quite good. The aroma is somewhat lacking with not much going on, but the taste is toasty malts with a nice balance of sweetness. The hops are more noticeable toward the end and offer and very subtle fruitiness with a quick bitter dryness. Overall really pretty good.

Poured from bottle to glass. Golden hue with creamy off white head that dissipated to a ring. Aroma is pine, caramel, citrus oil, tangerine, cereal. Mouthfeel is nice with a medium body and crisp carbonation. Taste is dry sweetness followed by a nice hop bitterness that extends through the finish. Overall this is a decent brew.

Bottle thanks to beerman6686. Pours a clear reddish orange with a foamy white head. Aromas of bread and caramel. Some grape skin and alcohol. Taste is slightly sweet with a bready aftertaste. Really easy drinking. A real "beery" beer.

Currently on tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and dispensed to a Czech-pils glass showing a lightly hazed, orangey gold color, and fairly lasting, off white/light tan head foam, with a wavy edge that turned into spots & ribbons of clingy lacing. The nose was lightly fruity as orange, light grain, and soft malt, with just a wisp of soapiness that might have been the glass. Light to medium bodied, with decent carbonation, the taste included a moderate but steady, earthy hop bitterness that lingered into the finish along with some subtle dryness. A very "to style" English Pale that was quite quaffable.

The aroma is floral, biscuit. The appearance is amber, white head. The flavor is perfume/floral hops, biscuity malts. The finish is floral, lightly citrus and sweet. Medium in body. Medium, lightly thin Good for an under appreciated style.
Poured a orange yellow with a light head. Aroma was a light wet hop aroma and toasty bread malt notes. Taste was a very nice maltiness not to sweet with nice breadyness notes finish nicely crisp.
Bottle: Poured a carbonated orange clear with a thin fast disappating head. Very malty nose with bubble gum. Taste is sweet malts with nice light bitter finish.

On tap at B&D. Slightly hazy light amber with medium off-white head. Aroma is caramel malt, light carbonation, and some thin small-bubble lacing. Taste is subtle herbal hops and caramel malt. Kind of plain.

Where and how:  GG , Bottle 355 ml.
Aroma Authentic, proper malt and hop profile but with extra depth and finer refinement than most Bitter ales. If anything to complain about is that maybe aroma was tad too sweet.
 Appearance :
Top: medium-lighter bright white cap with lighter rings.
Base: clear amber.
Palate :  medium full bodied, solid depth, proper to style carbonation.
Taste: Classic bitter. Malt work is especially well crafted. Such beers remind you what true bitter can be. Woody leafy even tad peppery hop side.
 Other notes  world class for this style.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a hazy orange color with a thin white head that settles to a film leaving a little bit of lacing. Aroma of caramel, toasted malt and a touch of hops. Medium body, good balance of malt and slightly citrus hops which come through now rather than the aroma. Fairly clean finish. Good beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Orange copper in color. Nice floral pine with some citrus aroma notes. Also a hint of caramel and toffee thrown in as well. Slightly sweet citrus flavor. Finishes dry on the palate. Overall, tasty... I actually would have thought this was an American Pale Ale more than an English Bitter.
Tap at stone. Pours slightly cloudy brown lots head and lacing. Flavours of breakfast tea cereal fruit. Taste light sweet light bitter. Medium body with medium carb.

From a bottle. Pours hazy bright copper with a fizzy white head. Tastes like bitter malt, grassy earthy, light grapefruit, dry and woody. Light/medium body and carbonation. Smells like earth, malt, grapefruit, fruity, and nutty.

Bottle. Pours mostly clear with fizzy white head. Aroma is cereal and toasted malts, light floral bitterness, and light oranges. Flavor is dry malts, smooth hop bitterness, light toast, and faint citrus notes; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a mostly clear orange-amber with a white head. Nose is some biscuit, some caramel, some fruity esters, and some earthy fruit (plum? cherry?). Flavor starts biscuity than moves to bitter than to mildly fruity then back to bitter and biscuity in the finish. Light to medium in body and a very nice bitter overall.

Orange copper color with a white head. Aroma is toasty malt. Taste is slight citrus with a slight herbal maybe mint note. Toasty and sweet malt. Nothing over the top, not underwhelming. Solid, not too thin.
Nose of cinnamon, a bit of caramel, oranges. Glowing orange-red color. Malty, bready flavor, spice, some citrus. Very well balanced, good malt showcase.

Really, I thought it was a step up from draft offerings 
At sports events, with the bitterness, albeit the slight 
Bitterness. #6 of 12 in the pack order.

Draft at Global Brew EDW. This was just plain good. It had pleasant fruit, yeast, mild bitterness, and a heavy malt bill. Really well done and it is a style that tends to have little difference from one to another.

Very enjoyable for what its not, over the top. And for beer camp, restrained in the hopping to allow the style to shine. light copper, extremely well balanced with nice interplay of malt and mild hops, caramel, slighht spice, light carbonation. good.

Medium amber pour with lofty head. Aroma has pleasing pine, caramel malt, and smokiness, but also hints of some strange medicinal notes as well. Kind of like cherry cough syrup. On the tongue there is slight bitterness. Taste brings dose of caramel malts with some roastiness. Again something weirdly medicinal. Not bad, but not my cup of tea.

This golden brown beer has caramel aroma and smokey flavor. It is very smooth and easy drinking yet has a lot a interesting levels of flavor which take time to develop fully on the palate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark copper body with a quarter inch of head. Bready aroma, with alcohol, line, sweet, fruity malts. Earth flavor with underlying herbal notes. Light line and perhaps a touch of citrus. Not on par with the quaffable British bitters. Another mediocre, boring Beer Camp offering.

12oz bottle picked up at BevMo 
Pours clear dark amber with a small beige head, spotty lacing. Aroma or toasted malts, bready and dark fruit. Taste is toasted malts, burnt toast, bitters and citrus peel, dry 
A nice bitter.

Sampled on 9/20/2014. This bitter pours a dark amber orange gold color from a 12oz bottle. Medium to large sized white foamy head. The aroma is caramel malt, fruity and sweet, with some citrus. A medium bodied bitter. The malts are caramel, fruity and sweet. The hops are earthy and citrusy. Good carbonation, nice balance. A nice bitter, semi-sweet caramel malts with some nice citrus and herbal hops. Very drinkable. Would make a decent session ale. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter
Pours amber and fairly clear. Not much head. Aroma of dough and biscuits, sweet malts, caramel. Taste was a good amount of bitter and sweet with caramel and toffee. Not bad.

Enjoyed on tap at Dusek's in Chicago, IL. This is fantastic. Appearance is a dark murky brown with a rich and frothy white head that laces to the glass. Aroma not too apparent, light malt. Taste is fantastic, very euro, nice bitterness with bready malt, light hop profile, very enjoyable. Best beer I've had in months.
16 oz draft pours hazy amber with a off white head. Aroma of malts, toffee, citrus and grain. Taste is caramel , toffee and some citrus.
Bottle to English Pint. Pours a cloudy medium yellow, with a nice white head. Some bitterness on the scent, and nice strong hop flavors on the taste.

16oz draft poured into a pint glass. Murky amber color, off white head that stays with the beer, and carbonation runs to the top. Toffee, butter, and faint peach make up the nose. Flavors of copper, salty caramel, finished by a mild earthy hop note. Thin to medium mouthfeel with slightly above average carbonation. Not my usual beer style but a decent pour.

Bottle from the mix pack. Pours deep hazy copper colored with a one finger white to off white head. Aroma of characteristic SN yeast, some light bitterness, bready malt, straw. Flavor is malty to the core, bready with some fruits in there like figs and apples, clean crisp finish of straw and sugars. Light bodied, crisp, medium plus carbonation. Not bad, easy drinking, seems on style, but a style that doesnt excite me that much. One of the better in the style for me though.
Biscuit and grassy aromas with some sweet citrus notes. Light orange yellow body and light white head. Sweet citrus lemon flavor and bready hop finish. Smooth on the palate.

Clear golden amber with a fair off-white head. Minimalist aroma, light malty. Tasty English style brew. Clean and smooth. For a style I typically dont enjoy, this was really nice. New Glarus always makes a solid beer. A nice beer for a cool rainy afternoon.
Some spice, kick to it. Bitter yet smooth. Well made. Esb can be hard to make pleasurable to me typically, but I like this a lot.

12oz bottle. Pours a dark copper with a white head. Fruity, caramel, biscuit. Not bad. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Box dated 6/19/2014. Beer itself dated 5/22/14.
This was poured into a pint glass.
The appearance was a hazy dark orange to brown color with a one finger white rocky head that held for a good minute before slowly dieing a decent pace. Somewhat speckled and foamy lacing was left in the wake.
The smell has the "English Bitter" standard of the light soapy and sticky toffee malts that can be construed as "bittered" in a nice way.
The taste was mainly malty sweet through a delicate caramel and toffee crispness.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sessionability to it. The carbonation was mild but still there toying with my tongue but allowing a nice sticky creamy coating of toffee sweetness.
Overall, another winner for the style by SN and New Glarus.

Bottle. Amber with a nice sheen and standard-looking thin head. Not much of an aroma to decipher. This drinks with a snappy American or Teutonic bitterness, and IMHO doesnt match the "English-style Bitter" mold at all. That said, its a quaffable and tasty ale, with a bit of sweet fruit backdrop and the aforementioned snappy bite. (#5728, 9/12/2014)
An ESB with west coast hops. Tall, thin, hop profile of malt and maybe a little bread crust. And a slightly fruity, bitter hop finish. Not totally on style, but still good. Drinkable and refreshing.

Poured from bottle into English pint. Pours a rich clear copper with a two finger head. Head pretty quickly dissipates to a thin skim. Aroma - nose is fruity hops with light grass and citrus underneath. There is also some biscuit malt on the nose as well. Taste is a really nice balance of biscuit and hops with less citrus than on the nose. Finish is long and malty, carbonation level is pretty high and prickly.

Draft - Sweet caramel, orange and a bit of light sourness with twig. Clear copper with a decent beige head. Caramel,light sourness and a perfumy twig. Finish is light bitter and some orange peel and very dry.

Mild yeasty aroma. Looks a tad hazy and its colored brown orange yellow. Big fluffy head. Taste is mildly bitter, presentable. Perhaps a little less behaved than the refined bitters. Decent co2. OK. Leaves some medicinal bitterness in the mouth for a few after the session. Burps nicely, heheh.

text: Draft at Stone Liberty Station. Clear orange color with a khaki ring. Aroma is light, sweet malt, chalk dust and a hint of oranges. Flavor is mellow with some metallic bitterness. Nice.

12 oz bottle from Biggie Liquors, poured into my NBB globe glass. Dark orange and hazy appearance with a sticky light tan head. Biscuit au glaçage herbacé un peu fané. Peu de complexité dans les malts, amertume tranchante et éphémère.

This one poured a lighter brown color with a beige head. Aroma was of grassy hops, bitter biscuits and caramel. Flavor was similar, mild sweetness, nice balance between buffering and grassy hops and complex caramel malt.

Oviedo, Fl. Market Square Liquor - 12 oz bottle - part of the 2014 Beer Camp Across America 12-pak. Pours a crystal clear amber-orange with a sticky off-white head that leaves a light film of lacing. Aroma has some sweet malts, bread and tropical fruit. Some floral notes too. Good balance between malt sweetness and hop bitterness. Finish is fairly dry with a tinge of lingering bitterness. Lively mouthfeel is perhaps its one flaw. Could be a little less carbonated. Very drinkable. A pleasant brew. More like an American pale than an English bitter though.

12oz bottle. Medium beige head atop clear amber body. Aroma is medium sweet, spicy/orange, some tea, floral, grapefruit. Taste is moderately sweet, orange/earthy/spicy, some licorice, lime, light biscuit. Light-medium body, light effervescence.

On tap. Pours a clear light amber/copper color with a thin off-white head . Some ok retention and lacing happening here. Aroma is light caramel malts and some earthy hops. Taste is nicely balanced. Appearance: A very brilliantly clear bronze bodied beer with a vibrantly fluffy white cloud head that looks like meringue topping on a pie. Good lacing on the glass. Truly a perfect looking beer. 

Aroma: I get a bit of spicy hop aroma; some woody and wet moss hop character.

Taste: At first it has a very rustic bread quality to it. I get a bread crust flavor followed by a bit of hop bitterness. Perhaps even a rye-like quality to it. I feel it is important to note that all of the malt flavor is bready and there is no caramel-like flavor that I pick up.

Palate: It has a good mild amount of bitterness and a slight twinge from the malt and hops. I would say it rests at an even keel of a medium bodied beer with a slight rough edge.

Overall: Overall it is a good beer. I think it put a good spin on the English Bitter style while keeping things inline. It is very easy to drink and quite enjoyable. I recommend it.

Flavor / Palate - A blend of light cinnamon, apple pie, and mild bitterness provides an all American take on a British style. The gentle fluid mouthfeel opens up with time. Poured from bottle into a pint glass
 Appearance  The beer pours an orange-amber color with a thick one finger white head that has fantastic retention. The head slowly fades over a long time to leave a light level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass. 
 Smell  The nose of the beer is sweet and malty with tons of caramel and toffee sweetness as well as a good deal of a grainy and toasted bready malt smell. Along with these aromas comes some smells of a sweeter fruitiness as well as a bit of an earthy and piney hop smell.
 Taste  The taste begins much drier then I would have anticipated from the smell with a toasted malt flavor along with just a bit of a more caramel sweet taste. The bit of sweetness that is present upfront fades as the taste advances with just a hint of a lighter butterscotch flavor taking its place. Joining the toasted malt flavor are some flavors of grain and a bit of a hay-like malty taste. Hop flavors are largely absent upfront, but as the taste advances some flavors of an earthy and herbal hop flavor come to the tongue. Along with a little bit of nut and a very light happening of some toffee, one is left with a malty and slightly dank hopped and sweetened flavor to linger on the tongue.
 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the thicker and creamier side with a carbonation level that is on the lower side for a brew of only 5.6 % abv. For the style and tastes of the brew, which consist of malty and dank hops, the thicker body and lower carbonation level are rather well fitting and make for a nice mouth coating feel.
 Overall  A decent bitter overall, but really nothing all that fantastic.

12 ounce bottle from the Beer Camp box. Light color. Strong nose. Really nice bitter hop profile. Solid.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2014 Draft. Herbal and tangerine nose. Flavor is mellow, very refreshing, some spice notes and herbs. Pretty decent. Draft again.

Bottle... Poured copper/amber with a mild forming head. Grains and earthy spicing on the nose. Soft, moderate carbonation and mouthfeel. Low bitterness, earthy, mild ale yeast esters, some resinous hops. Overall super clean and easy drinking. Short finish.

Bottle from beer camp 12er. Pours a clear light amber with a short lived off white head. Aroma is bready and earthy, with a hint of fruity sweetness. Flavor is cracker, caramel, blood orange, earthy and perfect. Well balanced with a juicy, sticky texture. My only gripe is that its a little overcarbonated

Pours light orange. Aroma is very floral and pleasant. Flavor is sweet and light grassy notes, very drinkable.

Beer camp day 2. Bottle pours a nice copper color. Mild bready, malt aroma. Toast malt flavor with a little fruit. Really nice hop bitter too. Overall, this is a really good beer. Flavor will stick around for quite a while. Really enjoying this one.

Ar: Pineapple, pear, perfume - toasted malt, biscuit - mossy.
Ap: Copper-gold, clear - medium off-white head with moderate retention, leaves a ring of fine bubbles and an almost-complete, thin cap of foam.
T: Biscuit and red apple - pineapple, toasted malt - medium-low bitterness, clean, woody and mossy - lots more biscuit, some pineapple on the finish.
P: Medium body with high carbonation - finish is dry.
O: Excellent bitter - the biscuit flavor and malt foundation is spot on - some really great English accents in the form of mossy hops and pineapple esters.

This beer pours a clear darkish orange color with a medium off-white head that stays on top of the liquid. The aroma, although fairly light, blends caramel malts and earthy and herbal hops, and the taste blends a mild bitterness, which is both malty and hoppy in flavor, and a slight sourness. The palate fuses a slightly sticky texture, medium body, soft carbonation, and a finish that is an extension of the flavor, which isnt necessarily a positive. Overall, this beer could have been great due to the partners, but it just falls into the mediocre category.
One of the better beers in the BC 12 pack. Tastes toasty and crisp with enough herbal malt to bring it together.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a hazy copper with a one inch head that lasts. Taste is of malt, barley, hops, citrus, tea, grapefruit, pine and resin. Similar aroma. Has a decent lighter body. Good, but not quite the English bitter I was expecting.

On tap at Busters pours a slightly hazy copper with a thin khaki head. Aroma of caramel and toffee with tropical fruits. Nice upfront earthy bitterness, smooth caramel toffee malts with fruity slight pine hops on the finish. Nice!
Bottle from the beer camp boxed set. Pours a brick red color that fades to dark sand. Taste is malty and easy on the palate. Taste lime it should be in cask
Bottle. Nose is light toffee. With some lemon. Slightly hazy pour with a small white head. Taste is toffee with some grass. Very nice.
Beer camp collaborative 12 pack. Drinking the by ibu. Lowest to highest. Color is great caramel. Aroma light. But for a bitter it is quite nice. Drinkable.
Bottle from the Beer Camp pack. Pours a clear amber color with a medium tan head. Aroma of malt, floral hop and caramel. Malty and caramelly flavor with floral hops before a nutty finish.
Bottle. Clean enough. Light herbal home. Bit of toasty caramel. Petes pretty tame

12oz bottle pours with a clear copper body that has thin gold edges and supports a tan head. The aroma offers up malts, firm biscuit and a dash of floral hops. The taste starts with bitter floral and spicy hops and then it heads straight into a mix of sweet fruity red apple like esters and biscuit malts. This has a nice malty biscuit smooth mouth feel punctuated by modest bitter hoppiness. Pretty nice.

Bottle to stein. The pour is a cloudy copper with a nice one finger head that recedes but leaves a decent cap. The aroma is fruity like lemons and oranges with caramel malts. The taste is more orange and malt with some earthiness as well. It's really bright and clean. The finish is thinner but not super thin with good carbonation. 
Overall this is a really nice beer. It definitely makes me want to try and get some New Glarus. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This beer pours a clear amber-orange color with a medium off-white head that recedes steadily. Roast malt, fruit and hops in the nose. Light-bodied with flavors of roasted malt, caramel and earthy hops. The finish is fruity and malty up front with a mild herbal hops aftertaste. Decent overall.

Btl pours cloudy light brown color with orange highlights. Thick, light tan head lingers leaving massive lace on glass. Smells of toast, flowers, herbs and earth.Tastes of sweet honey nut Cheerios,floral,herbal hops and a hint of spice. Medium body, tingly mouthfeel,good carbonation and a slightly sweet and spicy finish. Rich malt flavors combined with the bright,clean hop flavors and aromas make this an impeccable ale. I have had a few New Glarus brews and they were fantastic as well.

Draft the pours cloudy orange/brown with a wisp of a white head. Aroma is medium toasty malt with some floral from hops. English style bitter. Flavor was medium bitter and malts with that floral still there. Good representation of the style. Pretty mild considering but love it.

On tap at Beer Camp Across America southeast. Pours a golden brown with thin white head that leaves light lace. Aroma is nice toasted malts, nuts, earthy and floral notes from the hops. Taste follows, clean and easy, well balanced and nicely done. Good for the style.

Pours a hazy orange-amber with an off-white head and lacing. It has a light aroma of malt, some dark fruit, and a bit of earthiness. The flavor is sweet malt and some fruit up front with a long, sweet finish over a smooth, medium body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle in a teku. Pours deep copper with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma of toasty and pale malts, some floral hops with hints of earthy notes, and some dough. Flavor the same with a nice blend. Average texture. Not my favorite style, but this beer stands out as being really good for the style which is something that cant be said about a lot of beers in the 12 pack.
Bottle. Pours orange gold white head. Nose/taste of bread, orange peel, light fruit and toast. Lighter medium body.
On tap at Harrys Hofbrau. Malty with slight earthy hops. Clear copper with moderate white head. Taste is full cracker malt, with nice richness.

Bottle from Beer Camp Across America pack into snifter glass, ambery light brown color with light tan head. Aroma of toast, nuttiness, grain, light pine, floral and fruity hop notes. Taste adds notes of dough, orange zest, somewhat herbal and light earthy hop bitterness. Light-medium body, moderate-low carbonation, dry with light malt roast bitter finish. Pretty flavorful usually non-flavorful stye beer, many well rounded light notes.

12oz. bottle from the Sierra Nevada Collaboration Beer Camp 12 pack. Pours out a clear light brown with a little tan head, head fades quickly though to a very thin ring of tiny bubbles. Aroma is just fantastic, baked bread and light floral sweetness an amazing smell. Upon sipping you have a slightly spicy note, biscuits, light toffee. Light carbonation. Very nice beer, too bad I only have one bottle of it.

Deep golden pour with a thin head. Aroma of cereal and grain. Some flowery notes. Nice light mouth. Taste is full of cereal, clean, bright bitterness. Tastes like Im sitting in a pub in England. Slightly fruity. Bitter finish.

12 oz bottle. Amber with a faint haze and a decent off-white head. Aroma is of malt, toast, chestnuts, biscuit, some herbal hops. Taste is of toast, nuts, light marshmallow, biscuit, toffee, and malt.

Bottle. The look is clear with a slight haze, caramel colored, with a good off white head. The smell is pine, grainy, toast, nuts, floral, malt, hops. The taste is much the same with a nice richness, quaffable, hits the spot, and crisp.

on tap @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Medium amber color, long-lasting 2" off-white head, streamers of lace. A gentle malt begins the taste, moving through the palate without incident, adding a small hop presence which is plenty to balance. About as simple as a beer gets, but it still is able to deliver good taste.

Bottle to glass. Beautiful orange-brown pour. Nothing overpowering in the flavor, just a well-balanced and really good beer. Medium carbonation. A little malt lingers on the tongue--not very strong or caramely. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle: Pour is fairly clear, honey gold, with a chunky off white head into this pint glass. Retention is average , leading to a haze and a ring, with light spotting presence here. The nose is baked bread, caramel and toffee notes, with a hint of nut presence as youd probably expect for the style. Still - It is an appealing feeling. The flavor profile is initial soft bitter, moving to a hint of astringent, moving to bread and light floral presence - The hazelnut presence moves to a lingering sweetness near the finish line. I asked myself why theyd brew an admittedly tasty / boring english brew instead of an obvious lager - perhaps that was more work than they wanted to do for the collection. Oh well.

Bottle at home with my dad. Pour is clear orange with a small white head and good lacing. Perfumey, orange, caramelly, light biscuit, bready, and marmalade in the aroma. Taste is orange peel, bread, caramelly, light grassy, grapefruits, floral, and husky with a light bitter finish. Medium body with soft carbonation. Good stuff.

12 oz bottle from mix pack. Pours a hazy copper color with a medium white head that has fair retention. The aroma is muted with softened barley and a hint of citrus. The taste is lightly bitter with nuts, grains, yeasts and herbal hops. The palate is a but thin but effective for the style and the carbonation is soft. Finishes short and dry. Overall: a tasty little bitter...

Sampled at Beer Camp 2014 @ Navy Pier (Chicago, IL). Pours a deeper orange amber hue, a gentle haze with glowing Longhorn orange and fiery carmelized toasty hues. A frothy offwhite head atop stays small, rings and laces small overall. Aromas are a bit sweet, carmelized and toffee elements meet biscuits, faint nuttiness. Gentle earthy hop. Mellow overall. Initial is lighter end of medium bodied. Some toasty malts, decent biscuit and toffee. Touches of nut, some earth and soil. A bit sweet and bland, the backend shows some gentle earthy bitterness. Trailing carmelized feel. Ok.

12oz bottle from Spirits Brick. Poured a slightly hazy burnt orange with a smaller foamy off white head. Aroma is biscuit, tea bag, nut shells and bread crusts. Bigger body than I was expecting, full big chewy body with average carbonation and a quicker fading aftertaste. Flavor of crusts, nut shell, superdry citrus peel, chaff. Good stuff but why didnt New Glarus make some crazy fruit beer with some type of CA fruit?

Pours a clear amber-orange with a tall, tight-bubbled cream-colored head that settles slowly, leaving some big foamy lace. Nose involves toasted malt and herbal, woody hop notes along with some pine and peach. Fairly sweet, also fairly bitter. Medium bodied, oily, sprite and active, with a lengthy herbal hop finish. Nice brew, very drinkable with character, and I wish more American brewers would attempt something along these lines.

pours a copper body with a thick eggshell colored head. has a nice lightly sweet nose with a hint of cereal and some hay. definitely get the herbal hop note at first sip. but this has a nice malt background that keeps this enjoyable. a biscuity flavor works well with the hops and a light honey sweetness at the end rounds it out well.

Hey-sooz chree-stay these beers have lengthy stories! None of which I have the patience to read. Anyway, this one is amber, dark but translucent, and its white ring head lasts more than 30 minutes. The aroma is all-malt like livestock feed, which is kind of foul unless youre a teenage boy into "ranch" bullshit. It tastes as good as dos equis amber plus some mediciny, not medicinal, fake cherry flavor.

Brown amber color. Dark toast malt saves it from being a floral IPA. The hop presence is notable and, yes, somewhat bitter. Its a casual malty beer turned up a few notches. Not bad, but not really my thing.

Look: pours a copper color. With slightly off white head. Thin lacing.
Smell: bitter almost sour smell. pineapple. Bananas Dryness that's led my mouth water.
Taste: malt. Tropical fruit. Slight bitterness. Bananas 
Feel: dry. Leaves a slight film on the teeth., but definitely notice an IPA does. Low carbonation. 
Overall: ok beer. Not as bitter as expected.

Pours a slightly cloudy orange with an off white head. Aroma is mild with notes of roasted malts, a bit of resin, and hints of brown sugar toffee. Taste is moderately sweet with bitter notes throughout

Notes of fruit, toasted malts, and herbal hints greet the nose while a Rudy amber pour pleases the eye. The palate is met with toasted malts, florals, and herbal notes concluding with a hoppy bitter finish. Medium body and medium carbonation. Overall, well balanced and extremely easy to drink. Sadly only one in she box.
Orange pour with tiny white bubbly head. Aroma is toasted nuts. Taste is toasted bread, slight nuttiness, bold flavors, bitter finish. Extra carbonation.
7/31/2014. From bottle. Amber with a white head. Fruit forward with hints of peaches, caramel and spices. Malty flavors with spices and a light bitter finish.
Bottle from the sampler pack. Cracker and bread, some pepper. Subtle fruit element - apple and cherry. Absolutely one of the best in this style Ive ever had.

Bottle: Dingy, muddled burnt amber & slightly copper body with a chunky, porous eggshell head that leaves some fat lacing as it slowly recedes. Aroma with some caramel taffy candy, toffee, Munich malt sweetness, a hint of cherry, mild perfume, toasted nuts, a mild woodsiness, & a touch of earth. Taste has a more present fruitiness, some orange, mild citrus, & a twinge of black cherry. Hops themselves more present, too; earthy, woody, & just a touch spicy with a finishing floral staunchness. Toasted toffee malt backbone, notes of toast & mild nuttiness. Not as sweet as the nose would make it seem. An enjoyable English style bitter.
Kind of underwhelming. Pours an amber color. Aromas are some fruit. Apples maybe. Flavors are toasted wheat and bubblegum. Whatever.
UPDATED: JUL 31, 2014 Tastes likes a Brie cheese to me. Lactose. Not very bitter but interesting. On tap at jl beers grand forks.
Smells remarkably British. Little bit of sweetness at first then overpowered by bitter. Not bad for this style.

12oz bottle pours semi clear ruby dark red with one finger head. Nose is light sweet toasty malt, oats and subtle fruit. Taste is toasty malt fruit, oats, some soft medicinal cherry and evergreen. Finish is round mild bitter malt, semi sweet, fruit, faint grainy pine.

amber with foamy beige head; aroma is sweet fruity and hint of tartness(citrus-orange?); flava is mild yet rich sweet fruitiness upfront then mild hoppy bitterness blends in; feels light to medium with decent fizzy foaminess; finishes sweet and dry with bitter hops
Solid beer, but nothing exciting. However it a more simple style of beer. Could drink many of these. Most sessionable of all the beers so far.

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 7-29-14. Sophisticated, pleasant, malty, and a bit tart aroma features scents of toffee and caramel. Pours an amber to sable with a small to moderate amount of taupe head. Moderate effervescence. Mostly clear with some haze. Produces pretty good lacing. Meaty, dry taste features flavors of cracker, biscuit, and whole wheat bread. Light to medium body. Lively in the palate. Easy to drink. Overall, tremendously pleasant and likable but too subdued to earn an outstanding score. Definitively professionally produced.

Pours a light brown amber/copper color, like a redwood stain. The beer might be a touch hazy, or perhaps, its just the color. The head initially kicks up as a blanket of off white foam. Its a touch fizzy and fades away after a minute, leaving moderate lacing. Not the most vigorous. Mild but rich caramel in the aroma. A touch of cough syrup. Bready malt, a bit simple but nice. Some fruitiness, mostly strawberries, grapes, cherries and raspberries, but all sweet with no acidity. Mild hoppiness, some sort of herbal, earthy, mineral-ish spice in the background. Taste is fairly sweet. The malt is nice, but the sweetness climbs a bit much and takes on an off character with that cough syrup flavor, which Ive noticed in other English-style beers, as well. That same sweet fruitiness and mild hop flavor. Its a fruity, earthy flavor. Finish dries out some, ending with a mineral finish. Mouthfeel is quite full. Carbonation is fairly low. The beer does wash out a bit at the end. Decent beer and its always nice to try a less common English style.

12 oz bottle -- bottled on date 22 May 2014 -- served in a nonic glass.

Pours deep amber in color with a slight haze; very good, durable head and good lacing. Some rising carbonation bubbles. 

Aroma: mainly a blend of malts with a touch of spicyl/fruity hops. 

Flavor: Malty but well balanced and matched blend of malts and hops. Pleasant lingering malty flavor. Near equal sweet/bitter balance. 

Feel: medium body and medium, crisp but soft carbonation. Just right for style. 

O: an excellent and easy drinking version of the style.
Sweet grains, lemongrass and light caramel balanced with citrus and moderate bitterness. Finish is herbal and a bit sour and acidic. Not exactly blowing me away but also not bad.

The hops seem to have a bit of an American character to them so I would not call this traditional--good beer though. It is slightly jazzed and orange. It has a scant white head of mixed bubbles and just a little bit of lace. Its nose is a bit perfumy and floral with a touch of citrus. There is a subtle malt sweetness hate and a bit of fruit that seems to come from the yeast. It is full bodied and mildly carbonated, which suits the mild flavor in this case. It finishes with form bitterness and some lingering fruitiness. This is a tasty beer. I kind of wish they could have packed the same flavor in a smaller beer or brought a little more solid malt presence at the same strength but this works as it is really well as it is. Id drink it again.

There was a time when I thought bitters sucked, but I was so wrong. I love them now. This one is no exception!!! Great color of caramel and aroma of biscuit and malt with notes of caramel an light faint hopping. Flavor is crisp, moderate malt with plenty of biscuity notes and a caramel/toffee finish. Clean and enjoyable, definitely.

12 oz. bottle from SoHo Organic Market, Elizabeth City, NC. Deep orange pour with a frothy off-white head. Aroma offers caramel malt, nuts, and light citrus. The taste is much of what is detected in the aroma with the citrus and sweetness complimenting each other for a well balanced flavor. Represents the style nicely and is hands down the best bitter I have ever tried.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle. 2014 batch. The pour is vaguely cloudy and medium amber. The aroma has a nice malt sweetness and earth hop bitterness. The body is medium to full. The taste has an assertive bitterness coming up on the backside after the malt beginning.

Bottle PKGD 05/22/14. Nose is sweet and has a fruity-caramel character and its yeast-driven, but man are those cherries overripe! Pours amber-orange with light carbonation and a sudsy off-white head. Medium body, fruity and sweet but not cloying, some light bitterness and earthy caramel, cherries, light mineral, and these light strokes of rubbery-astringent malt, really super faint, like a pinch of black malt on your tongue here and there, but not detracting. Some pleasant phenol character here, too, and British water around the edges and my teeth. Surprisingly complex malt. Clean, balanced, fresh, zesty, refreshing. Not what I expected, but exactly what I needed. Excellent.
Bottle. Dark amber with a thick off white head. Aroma is fruity and floral. Taste is apple, tea, citrus and grass. Very bright. Thin with a prickly carb and short finish. Excellent.

A very good beer. I was originally going to rate this one a tad lower, because I wasnt getting a slippery malt note that I expect from this style. But, man oh man, the bitter part of it more than makes up for this! Fresh bitter (is that possible?) flavor. It hides in the background, but then makes its presence known, and stays around. Very nice.
Bottle. Pours orange gold with a big clingy off white head. Aroma of tart cherry skin, caramel, mineral. Flavor is caramel, mineral, grassy bitterness in the finish.
Nice copper color fruity overtones not too bitter a very nice smooth drinking bottle.

Bottle from the Beer Camp box. Pours a pretty clear amber with a long lasting white head. Aroma is identifiable as a bitter, but with a pleasant surprise of citrus. Admittedly, this is not a style I really get into but I can say this is one of the better English-style bitters Ive had. Everything is clean and well realized. The palate is on the light side, right in line for the style. Malts are a little toasty and earthy with hints at spice and citrus coming through a little. Very good balance. The problems I have with the style is a lot of metallic, vegetable or sugary malt flavors can be prevalent. None of those are an issue here. Nice job.

Bottle. Copper with lasting ring and a little lace. Herbal hop aroma with hints of caramel. Spicy herbal toasted caramel peach sweetness medium fruitiness with fairly assertive herbal hop bitter long finish. Medium body. Wonder if theres any rye in it. Good.
Bottle...Pout is clear caramel with a thin fading off white head..Nose is honey, some caramel, spice, ....Taste is soft caramel, some musty grains, spice..Pretty bland
Draft. Amber pour with white head. Light nutty and berry like fruit esters. Flavors are nutty and fruit like malt tones.
On tap at the brewery. Amber with tan head, bready malty aroma, apple sweetness, low carbonation.

My biggest dissapointment out of the 12-pack. I love New Glarus and I love English-styles. This one got stuck between stations - neither a good-stale drink-a-six-pack Fullers type of bitter, or an Americanized "amber pale ale" thing (think Southern Tier Harvest). As it stands, its just sort of there.
12oz bottle. Poured an amber color with an off white head. Caramel, some fruits, and some lighter citrus.
Bottle from nearbeer - thanks! brown, small head. Smells toasty, grassy - what I kind of consider typically "English". Taste is toasty, earthy malts and stale-ish hops. Some grainy notes, as well.
Orange pour with creamy white head and lace. Aroma is light malt and floral hops. Flavor is semi sweet malt with a nice earthy hop presence. Medium bodied with good carbonation. nice beer

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 5/22/2014. Pours lightly hazy orange/copper color with a 1-finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass, with some light streaming carbonation. Aromas of citrus zest, pear, apple, caramel, toast, biscuit, light nuttiness, herbal, floral, grass, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, earthy hops, and fruity yeast ester notes; with solid strength. Taste of citrus zest, pear, apple, caramel, toast, biscuit, light nuttiness, herbal, floral, grass, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Good amount of earthy/herbal bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of citrus zest, pear, apple, caramel, toast, biscuit, light nuttiness, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a short bit. Nice balance and robustness of earthy hops, dark/bready malt, and fruity yeast flavors; with a crisp malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, crisp, and slightly bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with zero warming present after the finish. Overall this is a nice English bitter. Good balance and robustness of earthy hops, dark/bready malt, and fruity yeast ester flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A nicely enjoyable offering.
Poured an amber color with aromas of toast, caramel, bread amber roman light citrus. Flavors match the aromas bready, caramel and toast, light orange peel bitterness in the aftertaste.

Bottle. Hazy dark amber pour with a small foamy head that fades to a messy ring. Aroma is slightly fruity with some oak, grass, light orange, and light toffee. Tastes pretty bitter throughout but not overpowering. Some nice light citrus, wood, and hay. Spicy finish. Not too familiar with this style really. Its enjoyable but it just feels like something is missing.

Hate to rate this on less than 3 oz or so, but maybe my last chance. Clear orange-copper with a lasting ring of foam. Nose is orange-herbal citrus. Tastes of the same great mix, with just enough dirty toffee to make it an ESB. Near-medium body has medium carbonation and a nice balance.
Pours a dark gold with a thick white head. Fruity ale yeast and floral hop aromas. Nice malt body, toasted malt and spicy hop notes in the taste. Nice well balanced bitter.

12oz bottle - pours a hazy copper with off white head . Aromas of toasted malt and caramel . Mild sweetness and tiny earthy hop note . Tasty . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a amber sienna color with two fingers of eggshell foam. Nose is toasted wheat bread, honey, fig and a hint of citrus. Palate is a balance of grain, honey and lingering fruitiness that falls into a bitter finish.

On draught during Sierra Nevada Beer Camp Across America event at Baileys Taproom. Clear amber golden color. Aroma is caramel, nut, grass, and apple. Taste is walnut, cashew, caramel, toffee, grass, and apple. Sweet and balanced ESB.

12oz bottle 7/27/14 (Beer Camp 12pk)-46° in English Pint-Pours a medium amber with a one finger off white head. Aroma of malt and hops. Taste of malt, caramel, and slight hops. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and goes down smooth.

Bottle. Pours copper with significant sediment at the bottom of my glass. Interesting beer, seems well-done, just not a favorite style of mine. Nutty malts, fruity hops, sweet with a dry finish. Medium body, lively carb. Not bad.

Reddish brown pour solid foam. Aroma of pine hops, maple malt. Tastes woody malt, pine, berries, tobacco. Could use more British yeast flavor. Americanized bitter with hops. A bit sticky on the palate.

Coppery orange pour with minimal head. Apple skin, raspberry, iced tea aroma. Traces of acetone and balsamic vinegar underneath lots of bready malt. 
Raspberry seed, tea-like bitterness and off color citrus pith overwhelm the weak malt flavor in short order. A fruit cocktail sugariness really thins it out if it wasnt there already.

Theres a lack of sufficient malt base and its so hollow, to an extent that just wouldnt be possible had New Glarus been in charge.
Bottle from BeerCamp 12 pk. Poured clear amber with diminishing head. Aroma of caramel rye malt. Light carb med bod. Semi sweet malty taste.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a light copper color with a big rocky beige head. Light grainy malt nose. Tangy toasted malt flavor has a hint of caramel. Spicy hops come through in the finish. Smooth and well balanced, with nutty notes in the aftertaste.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting.
Body is medium amber.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain, caramel), lightly to moderately hoppy (stale flowers, apricot), with a light note of black tea, hint of cardboard.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation.

A little faded already, it would seem, but not bad. They mostly got the "stale hops" odor of British ales, though.
Bottle from mix from Savor Grow. Copper pour, thin off-white head. Aroma of cereal and green apple. Tastes are grain, biscuit, caramel, herbal. Tingly carbonation. Nice.

Appearance is a pretty standard golden, light amber color with a white head. Aroma is grass, lemon, and bitter hops. Again, standard. Taste is a maltier version of the nose. A bit watery. Overall, its pretty good.

Bottle - Pours hazy amber with a creamy light tan head. Nose is toasty bread with hints of caramel sweetness, cereal, and very little hop presence. Straightforward toasted malt taste, with the same caramel sweetness and some grassy hops that peek through on the finish. Easy-to-drink yet tasty--exactly what Id expect from New Glarus. Fluffed up by carbonation, the body is medium-thin. Would like a 6-pack of this.

Clean malty aroma orange hazy pour. Thin head. Flowery and malty. Nice malty flavor. Good bitter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours an rich autumn orange with a thick head. Floral notes accompanied by cereal grains. Flavor starts of sweet, but finishes dry.

Bright orange color with tons of carbonation; slushy pockmarked head. Almost has the look of an amber lager. Aroma is bready; caramel malts. Bittering Euro hops. Flavor is sugary sweetness, very English. Doesnt have a ton of complexity, but its a lovely afternoon pub beer. Good for someone who doesnt have a specific preference.

Clear copper under a medium thick foamy off white head that smells of old world British malts and a touch of pencil shavings. Reaally weird flavor profile that features earthy almond tones an pencil shavings and a dark wheat-like malt body, with a dry finish and earthy slightly metallic bitterness throughout. Not a big fan.
Bottle-nonic. Dark copper with moderate offwhite head. A: grains, grassy hops, malt. T: same. Slight bitter end. OK.

Sampled from a bottle, 
this beer had a amber, burnt orange pour and presented an initial large, foamy white and some off-white bubbles that receded to a lasting layer, there was generous carbonation in the glass with many lively streams of bubbles, and it left nice spots and partial rings of lacing on the sides, 

it had aromas of light fruit that resembled raisin and pear, toasted malt, light citrus hops, and some malt sweetness, 

the flavors were nice toasted malt, faint caramel notes and light raisin fruit with light citrus and spice hops, 
the finish had a light hop bitterness with toasted malt following, the bitterness lingers a little afterwards, 

this drink was light and felt a little creamy on the mouth, and it had average carbonation, 

a very nice drink.

Bottled May 22, 2014.
Appearance: The body is clear with a light amber hue. The head is tall, dense and rocky with a light tan hue and good persistence.
Aroma: The aroma is mild with light orange marmalade overtones and hints of malty sweetness. A dash of caramel is noted. The aroma is balanced and smells nice, though it could use more strength.
Taste: Mildly bitter with orange marmalade coming through cleanly over a cracker malt base, slightly toasty with a mild sweet edge to it. Mildly sweet with a lingering mild hop bite on the finish. This is balanced nicely, very drinkable.
Palate: Slightly thick, nearing crisp though with moderate carbonation.
Overall: This should definitely be classified as an ESB, not a bitter. The ABV is off too far to be a standard bitter. Even so, this is a nice beer, one that I put up there with any other ESB that Ive had. Well done.

Nice, bready, woody malt aroma from a clear light orange/copper body with a medium white head. The aroma follows straight into the body with a light creaminess. At first this seems to be a fairly bland, watery beer, but as you drink it the flavor seems to build until it becomes a very enjoyable brew. By the time you reach the bottom of the glass, you want another one. A very subtle, very to style beer and another great addition to the Beer Camp Across America set.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2014 Orange golden, decent head retention and lace. Aroma is caramel, spicy hops, and sweet bread. Flavor is same plus some orange marmalade, faint lemon, British ale esters, and gentle bitterness that balances the caramel malt perfectly.

Bottle from the 24-pack. Pours copper with a thin persistent head. Not much aroma, nicely balanced on the palate, always love golden promise malt, touch of caramel malt, finishes fruity and dry. Overall, a nice beer but is it in the ESB style category? Kinda not.

Pours a pale amber color with an off white head and beautiful lacing. Malt, biscuit, grass, floral, toast and earthy aroma. Malt, caramel, biscuit, floral, light hop, grass, toast, citrus and earthy flavors. Medium body and carbonation. Dry malty finish.

On Tap at Bier:Thirty, Boise clear light amber with a small fleeting white head. Malty woody aromas, with a little boozy barrel notes. Soft light maltiness and a little bitter sharpness at the end. A bit sweet for the style maybe, but very pleasant.

The 2nd time around i really started liking this beer. Pours lightly hazy orange with a small eggshell white head and very sparse lacing. Nose is big bready malt, cracker, lite medicinal note, earthy hops. There really isnt a bad beer in this mix.

12 oz. bottle from the Beer Camp mix pack. It pours a clear, deep golden orange color with an off white head. The aroma is surprisingly citrusy with some caramel malt and herbal hops. The grapefruit citrus and herbal tea qualities meld nicely. The flavor is toasty with more herbal and citrus hops. Pretty hop forward with some fruitiness and an herbal bitterness in the finish. A very drinkable English style bitter.
